titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. V:15. Thursday. My wife, unexpectedly got home, between six and seven O’Clock this Morning; and brought with her Thomas Boyd, one of her Sister’s Sons, who went to Mr.W. S. Smith’s— Cardelli whom she met at Fredericsburg returning from Mr. Madison’s, came in the Steam-Boat with her. Cardelli called, about Noon, and brought me an answer from Mr Madison, to my last Letter— Cardelli has been a fortnight at Monticello and a fortnight at Montpellier, and has taken the Busts of Mr Jefferson and Mr Madison, much to his own Satisfaction and theirs. I received also a Letter from the President dated at Nashville, 14. June, with enclosures, which made it necessary for me to write to Mr Thompson the Secretary of the Navy, and to Mr de la Serna, the Spanish Chargé d’Affaires, which I did at the Office.— Compared with Mr Brent, the Manuscript of the Secret Journals of Congress. Mr Frye, Mr and Mrs W. S. Smith and Mr Forbes, were here this Evening.

2. IV:30. A person by the name of Henry Hillman came to me this morning, and complained that he had been dismissed without sufficient Cause from the Office of Overseer to the Stone cutters at the Capitol; and a foreigner and single man, put in his place. That he had been to Coll. Lane the Commissioner, who told him he had given all his authority to Mr Blagden, the man who had displaced Hillman; who had a personal pique against him—was a foreigner, and invariably partial to foreigners, against native Americans. I told him that I had no controul over the Commissioner, but if he would make a statement in writing of his complaint, and procure certificates of his good conduct and character, which he said he could, numerous and respectable, I would present them to the President, on his return— Sat to Mr King. Mrs Adams accompanied me to his house, but did not like the picture so that he changed its attitude— At the Office came Mr T. D. Anderson late Consul at Tunis, and now appointed to Tripoli— He came for Instructions, a Credential Letter, and upon an old claim for compensation as a bearer of despatches to Madrid. This claim must be settled by the President, it having arisen while he was Secretary of State. Mr Hyde de Neuville came to enquire if I had received late Letters from France; and he spoke again of his project of a Consular Convention— I told him as I had no Powers to treat, it would be necessary for me to wait till the President’s return, to give him an answer, and that probably he would prefer arranging a general Commercial Treaty, at the same time with the Consular Convention— He has this deeply at heart, and it has invariably been an object of high importance to the French Government under the Bourbons ever since their first Connection with the United States— It is all political machinery in the guise of Consular Regulations. Mr Jay’s Report upon the first Consular Convention, which I have read since de Neuville sent me his project, has disclosed to me the whole system. But de Neuville says unless there be a Consular Convention, it will be best for France to keep no Consuls here; as it occasions expence, and the Consuls have no powers— He asked also whether he and Madame de Neuville should call upon Mrs. Monroe to take leave— As I could not answer him upon this subject, he said the foreign Ministers were placed in an unpleasant predicament, by not knowing whether their visits would be received, and yet being unwilling to omit any mark of respect to the President’s family which might be expected. I told him I would make some enquiry, and let him know the result— Mrs Adams spent the Evening abroad.

3. IV:45. As the time of the morning Tides approaches I returned this Morning to my Bath in the Potowmack— The tide was low, it being about the period of the Neaps, and had turned about two hours before I was there. The morning was so cool, that it was rather an effort than a pleasure to go in to the water— At the Office, I received despatches from J. B. Prevost at St. Iago de ChileMarch last; after his return from taking possession at the Mouth of Columbia River. I made a draft of Instructions to T. D. Anderson, Consul at Tripoli, and of a Letter to T. Stith the Consul at Tunis. Received also a Note from the French Minister, concerning a Consular Convention. He and Mrs de Neuville came this Evening to see Mrs Adams, but she was gone out, to visit Mrs Monroe. Mr Bailey was also here this Evening.

4. V. Independence day— But being Sunday, its celebration is postponed till to-morrow. My Son John is this day sixteen. Bathed in the River. I had morning visits from D. Brent, Forbes, Cardelli, and G. Hay. Cardelli is in great agitation, from fear that he will not obtain employment as a Sculptor at the Capitol; and utterly averse to being placed in a station subordinate to his Countryman Andrei, who is also employed there. Mr Hay came to tell me that Mrs Monroe had determined not to receive the visit of Mr and Mrs de Neuville to take leave. He also entered into Conversation, upon General Jackson, the Seminole War, Arbuthnot and Armbrister, topics of which the interest has been for a moment revived, by the debate of the 11th. of May in the British House of Lords, a debate in which the Marquis of Lansdowne, took infinite pains to display his entire ignorance upon the long prepared and pompously fore announced subject of his own motion. Mr Hay seemed desirous to hear me talk on this subject, and I freely indulged him— The proceedings relating to it in both Houses of Congress, were so deeply tinged with electioneering colours, that the real merits of the question formed a very small part of
the causes of discussion— The controversy will be probably renewed hereafter, and thus I presume was the real intention of those who pursued it with so much inveteracy last winter— I employed the leisure of the day in reviewing my Account Books, and the Accounts of the last Month— Mary Hellen is unwell with an eruption upon the face— After dinner, I rode with my wife to Mrs French’s, beyond Georgetown, where we found Mrs S. B. Clarke with her child— The day was fine, and the Evening very cool.

5. IV:45. Morning Bath in the river. The Night and morning cool— At eleven O’Clock there was a procession from the Washington Hotel, to the Congress Hall on the Capitol Hill, where the Declaration of Independence was read by Mr Anderson, the Comptroller of the Treasury, and an Oration delivered by Mr Richard Bland Lee, formerly a Member of Congress— The procession was very small, and the Oration reasonably dull— At four O’Clock, I went to the Hotel on the Capitol Hill, where there was a subscription dinner, at which the late Mayor of the City, B. G. Orr presided. The dinner and management were very bad; and the company very small— Less than forty persons including the invited guests, the old revolutionary Officers— There were twenty-one toasts, but the State of Alabama being now the twenty-second State, I gave it as a volunteer; upon which Crawford who seems to have thought I was encroaching upon his territories, gave—“the admission of new States on the principles of the federal Constitution—that they should be Republican.”— This toast glanced at the failure of the Territory of Missouri, to become a State, at the last Session of Congress, owing to a restriction introduced by the House of Representatives, excluding Slavery from the State and declaring free all persons to be born there after a certain period— The Senate struck out the provision, and the Bill failed by the disagreement between the two Houses. The attempt to introduce the restriction introduced a violent agitation among the Members from the Slave-holding States, and it has been communicated to the States themselves; and to the Territory of Missouri. The Slave drivers, as usual, whenever this topic is brought up, bluster and bully, talk of the white Slaves of the Eastern States, and the dissolution of the Union, and Ocean’s of blood— And the Northern men, as usual pocket all this Hectoring; sit down in quiet, and submit to the Slave-scourging Republicanism of the Planters. Crawford who sees how this affair will ultimately go, and who relies on the support of the Slave Drivers, is determined to shew them that he is on their side; and gave this toast to exhibit himself as their champion— On this particular question I did not approve of the attempted restriction upon the State of Missouri, because I believed it not compatible either with the Constitution of the United States or with the Louisiana Treaty— But I think Crawford’s toast not remarkable for delicacy towards the Legislature; while the question is pending before them; and he an Officer of the Executive Government.— As he also flatters himself with support from New-York and Pennsylvania, I doubted a little whether this Toast was altogether judicious, in reference to its possible effect upon them— It may however pass unnoticed in that quarter. I was diverted at perceiving how it was brought out by my Toast of Alabama; the simplest thing in the world; originating in the oversight of the Managers, in preparing only twenty-one toasts— I withdrew immediately after these volunteers were given— Mr and Mrs W. S. Smith were here, in the Evening— There was a Comet visible, which sat about nine in the Evening; nearly in the North-West.

6. V:15. Notwithstanding the cool weather, I persist in bathing every Morning in the river while the tide serves; but this Morning I remained not longer than ten minutes in the water. I had promised to sit to King the Painter, at eleven O’Clock; but after I returned from the Bath, the Newspapers, reading and assorting, and breakfast detained me till past one, when it was too late. I called at King’s and postpone the sitting till the day after to-morrow. At the Office, Mr Poletica called— He returned from his excursion, yesterday; and brought me for perusal some papers concerning the Holy Alliance— An Instruction from the Emperor Alexander to General Van Suchtelen, his Minister in Sweden, and the Act of Accession of the Swiss Cantons to the Alliance— Mr T. D. Anderson, the Consul bound to Tripoli, came to take leave; and was anxious to obtain a further advance upon a prior unsettled acct. I declined giving it without a certificate from the 5th. Auditor Pleasonton, that there would in any event be so much due to him in the unsettled account, which certificate he could not obtain. I examined with Mr
Brent part of the manuscript secret Journal of the old Congress. Madame de Neuville, and Commodore and Mrs Decatur were here this Evening— Mr and Mrs Frye called with their child while we were at dinner, but did not stay, Mrs Adams and Mary Hellen, being both out with the Chicken pox. The Comet was again visible this Evening; being about one sign, distant, North of the Sun. It is large and bright, though less apparent, because the Harvest Moon, is just now coming to the full.

7. IV:30. Morning Bath. It was the day of the Full Moon, and the tide was high. I was again occupied with my old accounts, and was late at the Office. Stopped at the Metropolis Bank, and renewed my Note there for ninety days, with a repayment of 1000 dollars. Met Coll. Tayloe there. The widow of Franzoni the Italian Architect, who was my next door neighbour, and died suddenly some weeks since, came this Evening with Mrs Andrei the wife of another of those Architects, to solicit my assistance to obtain that she should be paid for the whole quarter during which her husband died, his Salary— I promised to do any thing in my power for her, but I am afraid it is unprecedented, and would be objectionable as a Precedent— Evening visit from Mr Poletica.

8. V:15. Some accident or newspaper paragraph put me last evening upon examining the par of exchange between the United States and England, which brought on Logarithmic calculations of the comparative value of the silver and gold coins of the two Countries. It swallowed up the last Evening, and this Morning with the exception of the hour and a half for bathing. I took Philip with me to the river. Sat between two and three hours to King— Captain O’Brien came to the Office about his claims, which must be referred to Congress. I attended this Evening a Ball given at parting by the French Minister Hyde de Neuville— There were between two and three hundred persons, and the heat was insupportable. Mrs Adams not being entirely recovered, did not go, but spent the Evening with her Sister Smith— I played Chess with Judge Thruston— Came home about eleven.

9. V: Morning bath. I received a Summons to attend the Circuit Court of the District, this morning, upon the trial of Mark and Francis Braconnier, two young Frenchmen living here, and exercising the trade of Silver-Smiths. They were indicted upon two charges; one of having counterfeited the current silver coin; and the other for having uttered counterfeit coin. I was summoned on their part to testify to their characters. I knew nothing of them personally; but Antoine had occasionally employed them for work, and was well acquainted with them. Their character as far as I had heard any thing of it was good— I attended the Court and took Antoine with me. It was past Noon before the trial came on. The eivdence against them was that they had passed to several persons about one dollar’s worth of counterfeit 16ths. of a dollar, commonly called here five penny bits: but there was no evidence of their having made them. The Story that they told was that a foreigner came some time since to their shop, with a handful of these five-penny bits, and ordered them to make waistcoat buttons of those with the best impressions, and to take the rest for their pay. He had also ordered them to procure other five penny bits, and make buttons of them. They produced a witness who swore that he was at their shop, when this man came, and gave them the order and the five-penny bits.— The strongest circumstances against them were that being Silver-Smiths they should have received and passed off these pieces for genuine money; the bare inspection of them being sufficient to shew that they were not of good silver. The only explanation of which, consistent with their innocence was that coming from a country where genuine small coins are made of debased metal and being foreigners here, they might know these pieces to be bad silver, and yet believe them to be genuine coins. They had also requested the attendance of the French Minister, who did not come, but sent Mr Thierry, with a certificate in their favour, and of the Viscount de Quabeck who neither came nor sent. The trial lasted till past two O’Clock, although the arguments of Counsel, both for the prosecution and for the defendant’s were very short. There was a Silversmith upon the Jury, who was sworn, and testified that he should have known by bare inspection
that the pieces which were produced in Court, and which they had passed, were counterfeit— Walter Jones the District Attorney, and of course the prosecutor, told me that there were bad reports in circulation against these men; and among the rest that when their shop was burnt down last Spring, coining instruments and a box of Counterfeit half-dollars were found there— He asked a question of Mauro, one of the witnesses, whether he knew any thing of this, or had heard such reports at that time: Mauro answered that he was at the fire; and saw every thing in and about their shop.— That he saw nothing of the kind; and never heard a surmise of it until within these two or three days. I left the Court-House before the Jury came in with their verdict— They acquitted both the Prisoners— Antoine entered his name as a foreigner intending to apply for naturalization, after he shall have resided in the United States, the five years required by Law— I rode to my Office; and was there informed by Mr Brent, that a vessel had arrived this Morning at Alexandria, in thirty days from Cadix. The Captain of which brought intelligence that the Treaty of 22d. February last, taken out by Mr Forsyth, had not been, and was not likely to be ratified. The cause, was supposed to be the interference of the British Government— This account was in the City Gazette this afternoon, and Mr Hyde de Neuville came this Evening to my house much occupied with it— He had this day received a Letter from Mr de Mun of 27. April, in which he says that the Spanish Ambassador at Paris was extremely dissatisfied with the Treaty; and that the English Ambassador, declaimed against it, even in an indecent manner, from which he concluded that the British Government would do every thing in their power to prevent the ratification of the Treaty— Mr de Neuville was also much out of humour with the determination of the President’s Lady, Mrs Monroe, not to receive Madame de Neuville, on a visit to take leave. The Comet was this Evening very brilliant.

10. IV:45. As the tide no longer serves for bathing before my breakfast hour in the morning I suspend again my river bath, although the weather which this day came on, Fahrenheit at 88. is better suited for bathing than it has been during the week that I have bathed; which has been generally cool. I was to have sat, this day to Mr King, but becoming engaged with my old Accounts, was again too late, and we postponed the sitting till Monday. Mr Hyde de Neuville was at the Office, and said he expected to leave the City for New-York, next Monday. We had some further Conversation upon the eighth Article of the Treaty with Spain, of which I promised him a copy to take with him to France— There was a false report from Cadix this day, through Boston that the Treaty had been ratified— It is by an arrival nearly three weeks of older date than the one at Alexandria— I rode out this Evening with my wife and Mary Hellen— The heat quite oppressive, and almost total calm.

11. IV: I rose twice in the Night with the intention of having a morning view of the Comet, but was disappointed. And when I rose for the day at four O’Clock, Jupiter and Venus were both conspicuously visible, but no Comet to be found. Yet the Newspapers say it has been brighter in the Morning, than before it sets at Night— The day was intensely warm. Fahrenheit at 92. but a fresh Southern breeze made it supportable, and by our dinner hour at 6. P.M. had brought up a violent gust of wind, accompanied with distant thunder and followed by a light shower of rain. It passed over in the course of an hour, and I went with Mrs Adams and Mary Hellen to Mr Frye’s, where we spent an hour of the Evening— The weather was but little tempered by the gust and rain— I this day commence the fifty third year of my age.

12. V:15. A Mr Stull brought to my house a draft of Bernard Henry, the Consul at Gibraltar, for monies, (two hundred Pounds Sterling) advanced to W. D. Robinson, an American Citizen, who has been two or three years confined as a prisoner in Mexico, and at the Havanna, and who lately escaped from Cadix to Gibraltar, by breaking his Parole. As the Government of the United States had made repeated applications to that of Spain, to obtain his release, Mr Henry thought it probable they would pay Mr Robinson’s debts— He had however directed Mr Stull to withdraw the draft, if objection should be made to accepting it. I told him there was no appropriation from which it could be paid, and he took it away. He told me that he had seen a Letter from Gibraltar mentioning first a report that the Treaty had been ratified, but afterwards stating that the writer had seen an official account from Madrid that it was not ratified on the 28th. of May— I had engaged to sit to Mr King the Painter; but the heat of the weather was so insupportable, that I called at his lodgings, and
postponed the sitting till the day after to-morrow. At the Office I had a copy of the abortive Treaty with Spain made out, to send to Mr de Neuville, and I made a draft of observations upon the 8th. Article, to remind him of the point of discussion upon that Article at the time when it was drawn up; and upon which de Neuville himself had made a written Memorandum at the time— Mr Forbes, and Mr and Mrs W. S. Smith were here this Evening.

13. V:15. A Mr Pomeroy of Windsor in the State of Vermont came this Morning to solicit employment, and to recommend a machine invented by his partner Lemuel Hedge, and for which they have a patent, for ruling paper. It performs the operation of ruling both sides of the paper at once; like Königs printing Press. But they lost all their property last Spring by fire, and now their only resource is the sale of these machines— Pomeroy wished for an introduction to the Russian Minister; I told him to call at his house and I was sure Mr Poletica, would readily receive him— I called at a Mr Brown’s shop in F. Street, near the Bank of the Metropolis, and saw one of the ruling Machines— Its construction is simple and they say a ream of paper can be ruled with it in 13 minutes— This Evening, with Mrs Adams and Mrs W. S. Smith we paid visits to Mr and Mrs Anderson— And afterwards Mr and Madame Hyde de Neuville came and took leave of us upon their departure for France. There was another false report from Gibraltar, of 3. June, that the Treaty with Spain had been ratified— Mr Calhoun the Secretary at War, arrived this Evening from Carolina.

14. V:Alexander Wilson a Quaker belonging to Philadelphia, to whom on the 24th. of March 1795. I gave at the Hague a Letter to General Moreau, then commanding the French Army at Utrecht, to enable him to pass through the army, on his way to Hamburg, called to see me this Morning. Soon after that incident, he returned to Philadelphia, where and on a farm within five miles of which he has ever since resided— He has now a wife and children, and is returning from a Summer excursion, with them into the State of Ohio. He told me the course of his adventures, after I gave him the Letter until he returned to the United States, and he recollected the particulars of his transactions with me, at that time, more circumstantially than I did— I found upon recurring to my diary that he remembered them correctly— Cardelli came to ask my advice, with his hopes and his fears. Coll. Lane has not given him employment upon his business as a Sculptor— Mr Jefferson’s bust which he left at Monticello to be forwarded from Milton has not yet arrived, and he is afraid it may be lost or damaged— He is extremely averse to return to work at the ornaments of Cornices at the Capitol, and yet he must work for his subsistence. I advised him at all events to return to his work; and wait with patience till Coll. Lane gives him something better. He said money was not his object, and he would offer to work at his proper business, for the same wages now given him for making eggs— I brought up my old Accounts in my Waste-Book, and Journal to the close of the last year. My transactions of private pecuniary business have been to an amount sufficiently important, and sufficiently complicated to require that the accounts of them should have been kept by the mode of double entry. I ought to have begun keeping them thus in 1790. when I commenced life in the practice of Law. But Book-keeping is not taught as a part of Classical Education, which is a great oversight, and I had neither learnt it, nor was aware of its importance. I had indeed no property, and for two or three years very little business to book; yet of that little, and of all my expences I did keep accounts, though not in a regular system of Books. When I went to Holland in 1794. I commenced in the Book which I have since used as a Ledger, a regular account of my receipts and payments on public account, and also of all my expences; but none of other pecuniary transactions. I found the want of it by experience; and upon resuming the practice of the Law, after my return from Europe in 1801. I began to keep regular Books— A Waste-Book and Journal in one; and a Ledger— My own agency, for my father; with the Bankruptcy of the House of BirdSavage and Bird, and its consequences; my wanderings about the world; my brother’s agency of my Affairs, of which I was at one time three years without any account, and the great variety of affairs in which I have been concerned, have not only produced some confusion in the formal part
of my Account Books, but some confusion in my ideas as to the mode of keeping them. I have made no entries in the Ledger since 1814. and never attempted the experiment of making out a Trial-Balance. I have but very imperfect catalogues of my Library, and no proper Inventory either of my household Furniture, or of my Real Estate— On my last return to this Country, I suspended making entries, in my Waste-Book and Journal, till I could enter upon it a summary of my brother’s agency Accounts during my absence in Europe. Last Summer I went through a partial examination of them, which I have now resumed and completed— In the mean time, my entries upon loose papers, had run up to nearly three sheets; which I have at length transferred to the Waste-Book and Journal; and in scrutinizing the modes of making the entries, I have ascertained the sources of most of the errors in my former entries. It remains for me still to revise and correct them; for which I must wait, if it is destined to me another period of leisure— I Sat to King the Painter, who being dissatisfied with the Portrait which he has taken, this day began another— At the Office General Mason came and introduced a Mr Robertson, who has been recommended by General Ripley, and employed by the War Department at the Havanna. He has been soliciting to be employed there again by the Department of State; but we shall have no present occasion for sending to Havanna— Young Brown, son of Mrs K. Brown of Georgetown, came with a Letter from her, to solicit a place, of Clerk, said to be vacant in the War Department. He had also a Letter of Recommendation from Genl. Mason, to Mr Calhoun, to whom I advised him to apply immediately, and promised to speak to him, in his favour. Mr and Madame Hyde de Neuville left the City this Evening.

15. V: In my earnestness to bring up my old accounts, I had again neglected my daily diary, till I had this morning three days to recover. It employed the time till near Noon, when I gave a sitting of two hours to King. Called at the Branch Bank; at the Office I received a Letter with enclosures from E. Fromentin. Continued the examination of the Secret Journals of the Old Congress for publication. There was a light thunder shower this Evening without rain enough however to moisten the ground— Made a very short Evening.

16. IV:30. MrJames Greenleaf came to solicit the appointment of Commercial Agent at Port au Prince, for Andrew Armstrong of New-York, whose name he left with me. I brought up all the arrears of my Accounts in my Waste-Book and Journal; and called at the Office of Mr Anderson the Comptroller; requesting him to take up my Accounts during my last Missions in Europe for Settlement. He promised me that he would the next week as he has often done before— I called upon Mr Calhoun the Secretary of War at his Office, and we had much and various conversation upon the most interesting topics of the time, in relation to public affairs. He thinks we shall unavoidably come within a year, to a paper money currency; and I believe he judges rightly. We shall come to it and to all its unjust and cruel consequences. The last of which to be dreaded is a civil War between Debtor and Creditor. Mr Crawford and Mr Calhoun were afterwards at my Office. Crawford wishes to employ two new Revenue Cutters to take a small piratical vessel, roving between Mobile and Florida Point; but the Captain cannot be commissioned till the President returns— We concluded that the Secretary of the Navy, might put them in the mean time put them under the command of Officers of the Navy. Mrs Adams went this Evening to Mrs French’s and saw Mrs Clark, who is ill with the meazles. Mr Poletica, and Mr Lomonossoff spent part of the Evening here. Poletica will be a very troublesome personage. He concludes that Mr Campbell will return immediately to the United States, because he has had the misfortune of losing in one week the three children whom he took with him to Russia, and Poletica enquired as an affair of confidence whether there was any chance that Levitt Harris would be appointed the Minister in his stead. He intimated that Harris himself had solicited him to use his influence to obtain the appointment for him. He made a number of impertinent observations, about Harris’s being a man of fortune, and about the necessity the President was under, of appointing persons who had distinguished themselves by public services.
He also remarked that Lord Liverpool and Lord Castlereagh used to make to the Russian Ambassador, confidential Communications like that which he now inofficially asked— I told him that the Heads of the British Cabinet knew before-hand who would be appointed to Offices, for the appointments were made by them— I had not the same authority; and could not tell him whether in the Event of Mr Campbell’s return home, there would be any chance for the appointment of Mr Harris. The event itself of Mr Campbell’s return so soon had not been anticipated, and there was no nothing but conjecture upon which its probability was inferred— I see that extreme circumspection will in future be necessary in my relations and intercourse with this man, and am very apprehensive that will not be sufficient to keep terms with him.

17. IV: The time of tide is returning at which I can again bathe in the Potowmack, before breakfast; which I did this Morning. Mr Thomas Law called this day on a visit— I sat two hours to Mr King. Received a Letter from the President of the United States, dated the 5th. of this Month at Lexington Kentucky; he shortens his tour and returns by the nearest road, to his Estate in Albemarle County, Virginia. Received also Letters of 1. May from G. W. Erving at Madrid— Forsyth had not then arrived there— These Letters leave no doubt that the Treaty of 22. Feby. will not at present be ratified; and that every thing concerning our relations with Spain is again afloat under circumstances of greater difficulty than ever— Mr and Mrs Frye with their infant called here, while we were at dinner, and Mr Bailey was here in the Evening. [symbols]

18. V:30. The weather has become so cool that I omitted the bath this morning. Mr George Hay came to say that Mrs Monroe and the President’s family do not intend to go and meet him at his house in Albemarle County, as he expected they would; but that after stopping there a few days for repose, he will return to this City. Hay spoke of the state of Affairs with Spain, and expressed quite an unfavourable opinion of Forsyth, who he said was a man devoured by Vanity. Mr Thierry, now acting as the Charge d’Affaires of France came to say that he had been with Mr. and Madame de Neuville to Baltimore, whence he returned last Evening. They had proceeded the day before on their Journey— I received despatches from A. Gallatin, dates to 31 May; but nothing important— I took a short walk over the fields before dinner, and in the Evening, with Mrs Adams and Mary Hellen paid a visit to Mr Middleton and his family at Kalorama. He has just returned from Carolina. W. Lee’stwo daughters were there, and he came in afterwards himself. I wasted much of this day; and made an ineffectual attempt to resume my Report upon weights and measures.

19. V:15. Had a severe cramp in one leg this morning before day-break. Bathed in the river. Returning home, I stopped at the house of Mr Ironside, who keeps a school for boys. As my Son John is to enter the University at Cambridge this Summer, I propose to take his younger brother Charles, from Boston where they have been two years at the town Latin School together, and boarding at Dr. Welsh’s— My object was to enquire of Mr Ironside, if he knew and practised the course of Instruction for preparing students for Cambridge— He said he was, and that he kept his school now, entirely for teaching the Classics. His terms are 200 dollars a year for board and tuition—and 15 dollars a Quarter for tuition alone. He gives only the Saturday for a weekly Holiday; and the Month of August for a Vacation— Mr Anderson the Comptroller, called here at the request of Mrs. Gantt and Mrs. Ewell the Sisters of Mrs G. W. Campbell, to ask if we had information of that terrible calamity which has befallen her, in the loss of three children in one week at St. Petersburg— I gave him J. D. Lewis’s Letter to my wife, containing the account. It is a subject upon which I have not fortitude to think— Dougherty came to solicit again a re-appointment as Superintendant of the building where the Offices of the State, War and Navy Departments are kept; from which he was removed for having assaulted and beaten Coll. Lane— He has been prosecuted for the same act, and sentenced to 30 days imprisonment and to pay a fine of 50 dollars. He has just been discharged from the term of his imprisonment, and asked me if there was any chance of his obtaining
a re-appointment to the place from which he was removed. I told him in candour, I thought there was none— First because the place is already filled— Secondly because the transaction for which he was removed was of a character that could not be overlooked; and thirdly because no person would be appointed without the sanction of the President, who was highly offended with him.— He said he knew the President was prejudiced against him; and if he should interfere, there was no chance for him; but he did not see what the President had to do with the appointment. I assured him that no person would receive it without the President’s approbation— At the Office I had many visitors— Captain O’Brien with his never-ending and inexplicable claims. Mr Anderson and his Son, of New-York; just now from Michillimackinac; who were introduced to me by Mr William Lee— Anderson says he met me last September in the Steam-boat from Staten-Island to New-York. Mr Jamison, who came with a complaint from an Insurance Company at Baltimore, on a piratical capture, and a claim at Port-au-Prince; and Mr Poletica, who came, without business; but perhaps to pick up crumbs for a despatch— I wrote to Antrobus and to the President— Mrs Adams passed the Evening abroad. The Comet was again visible, but grows nightly more dim.

20. V:15. The last Night and this Morning were so cool, that I again omitted going to the bath. But wasted the hours in calculations of the par of exchange between the Coins and their Standards in the United States France and England. I sat two hours to King; and at the Office did little else but examine the Manuscript of the Secret Journals of the Old Congress. Mrs Adams with Mary Hellen went this Evening to the Theatre. Mr Forbes and Mr Stackpole of Boston, called upon me this Evening.

21. V: Morning Bath. Absorbed in Logarithms and Exchange— Sat two Hours to King, who is taking two Portraits at once— Mr Crawford, the Secretary of the Treasury called at my Office, and said he had concluded it would be best to Commission at once the Commanders and Officers of the two Revenue Cutters, and if I would issue the Commissions, he would take it upon himself to give them; to which I agreed— He gave me the name of Jairus Loomis the man who blew up the Negro Fort, as Commander of one of the Cutters; and two names for Mates of each of the Cutters— For the Commander of the second Cutter he said he must wait to hear further from the Collector at New-York— I asked Crawford how his returns of revenue hold out. He says they are falling off in Virginia, and Bonds are laying over, elsewhere. The Banks are breaking, or as they call it suspending Specie payments all over the Country, but the United States Bank, is in a great measure relieved from the pressure that was bearing upon it— They will lose however by the Baltimore swindlers about two Millions of Dollars— My wife was unwell, confined great part of this day to her bed.

22. IV:45. Bath in the Potowmack. Took Philip with me. It was the morning of the new moon, with a blustering breeze, which dashed the waves at the face, and some of the river water down my throat. It had the aspect of blowing up rain, which is much needed; but passed over with a very slight sprinkling. Mr Richard B. Lee called at my house to enquire if in the Event of Ratification of the Spanish Treaty, British grants of Lands in Florida, made while the British owned the Province would be valid. I told him they would be as valid under the Government of the United States, as they were under that of Spain; but that he might spare himself the trouble of any further enquiry, at least for the present; there being no prospect of the Ratification— He spoke of a grant of two millions of acres from Tampa Bay to the river St. John’s, which I presume cannot be valid. I wasted my time again in enquiries about Coins and Exchange. At the Office I received a Letter from the Commissioner, C. P. Van Ness, and wrote to him. Evening at home. Mrs Adams rode out with Mary Hellen.

23. IV:45. Bath in the river alone. Sat two hours to King. A severe drought has been prevailing here several weeks. The change of Moon brought the prospect of a change of weather. This day was cool, and I returned home from my Office in a shower, drizzling between Mist and Rain. Received Letters from Purviance, dated 30. May at Bordeaux, and from D. Strobel the Consul there of 31. May. Purviance landed 28. May, after a Quarantine of ten days, in the Garonne. G. W. Erving arrived at Bordeaux from Madrid the same day with Purviance, and says the Treaty will not be speedily ratified. Purviance 30. May, writes that he had concluded not to go to Madrid
yet Strobel the next day writes that he had gone on that Morning to Bayonne— Not a word either from Erving, or from Forsyth.

24. V: There was a little rain in the Night, and the Morning being cool and lowering, I omitted my usual bath in the river. I was swallowed up in calculations and meditations upon Coins, Currency and Exchange, the only excuse for which that I can devise is the connection of the subject with weights and measures; upon which I am called to report to the Senate— Sat again to King; another noisome encroachment upon my time— There were several light showers in the course of the day. Mr and Mrs Middleton, with their two daughters were here, this Evening; and W. S. Smith. Mrs Adams and Mary Hellen spent the Evening at Mrs Smith’s.

25. V: A very heavy thunder shower in the Night, but without clearing or cooling the atmosphere. I bathed in the river; the last time for this Series of tides. When I came home, I found Cardelli; still complaining that he has not received Mr Jefferson’s Bust, nor an answer from Mr Jefferson to a Letter; which he wrote to him about it— I plunge deeper and deeper into my enquiries, concerning Coins, Currencies and Exchange—the deeper I go, the deeper, and the darker appears the deep beneath; and although the want of time will soon force me to break away from the subject, without even finding its bottom; yet it now fascinates and absorbs me to the neglect of the most necessary business, and even of my daily diary. W. S. Smith and his wife dined with us— The Ladies rode out after dinner, and I had a long Evening visit from Mr Poletica— A late Evening Shower.

26. V: A Showery day; with Thunder, and intervals of sultry heat. To recover the arrears of my diary I was obliged to intermit my examinations of the Currency, Coin and Exchange Subject. Sat to King. Mrs Monroe sent me a Letter to the President from a man at New-York named Hardy, petitioning for a respite for his son, who is under sentence of death, for desertion, from the army, after having been once pardoned for the same offence. I took the Letter to Mr Calhoun, who promised to have a Letter written to Harvie, informing him that the sentence will not be executed, before the President shall have seen and considered his Letter— It will not be executed at all; but perhaps commuted. Captain O’Brien, came and besieged me again with his old Algerine claim; which was settled by Mr Madison while Secretary of State; and it avails me nothing to tell the old Jack-tar, slave-consul, that I have no power to revise and set aside that settlement. He brought me another budget of papers, to look at, through the Spy-glass, as he expressed it— And seemed disappointed at my persisting to assure him that Congress alone could provide for the further satisfaction of his claim— I rode home from my Office— Mrs Adams spent the Evening abroad at Mrs Meigs’s.

27. IV:30.Mr Wrifford the teacher of writing came this morning, with specimens of the improvement made by some of his scholars in a course of twelve lessons, of which he had certificates from Mr Anderson the Comptroller and William Lee. He wished me to sign such a certificate, which I declined. Sat again for my Portrait to Mr King— Called at Mr Calhoun’s Office with two Letters, received, one yesterday, the other this day from A. Gallatin, shewing the prospect that the Treaty with Spain will not be ratified. This Evening, with Mrs. Adams and Mary Hellen, I paid visits to Mrs Crawford, and afterwards to Mrs Monroe. Mr Crawford had gone to the Theatre— Mr and Mrs Hay, Maria Monroe, the President’s youngest daughter, and Mr Hay’s daughter, Hortensia, were there. Mrs Hay had been quite ill— The Showers and Thunder have scarcely yet cooled the atmosphere.

28. V: Wading deeper and deeper into currency, coins and exchange. At the Office, Captain O’Brien came with another budget of papers for my examination— It is a great and painful effort to persevere in resistance to the importunities of claimants and solicitors, without loss of temper— O’Brien is an old Irishman, who was once Consul-General at Algiers; chiefly because he had been nine or ten years a slave there. He was a Master of a vessel, and is an exact copy of Smollett’s novel Sailors. His discourse is patched up entirely of Sea-phrases; and he prides himself upon nothing so much as his language— Eleven years after having had all his Accounts settled, he comes and advances claims to an amount little less than 30 000 dollars, without the vestige of
of a new document to support them. He brings me bundle after bundle of papers to read and examine and persists in spite of my assurance ten times repeated that I have neither authority to revise his Accounts, nor funds to provide for his claims. The great difficulty in such cases is to preserve good humour, and it has its inconvenience too. For these importunate people, take mildness for encouragement, and consume time and Patience in proportion as they are endured. Mr F. Adams of Alexandria, brought me a Letter from Judge Cranch. He has been appointed Consul at Trieste; but now applies for that of Marseilles, vacant by the recent Death, of S. Cathalan; and a better place— The Candidates for it swarm of course— I received two packets of despatches for Mr Poletica, from a Captain Vermilye at New-York. He brought them from Havre, and they have been broken open, and abused by Pirates, who boarded and plundered the vessel on her passage— One of the Packets was a Commission to Mr Ivanoff as Consul General of Russia, in the Room of Kosloff— I sent them to Poletica, with Captain Vermilye’s Letter. He came, and shewed me a despatch from Count Nesselrode dated in February, containing piteous lamentations upon the change of Ministry in France, and a warm panegyric upon the Duke de Richelieu and he read me part of a private Letter from Pozzo di Borgo, dated 20. May, chiefly filled with speculations on French, German, Italian, and Spanish politics— All disclosing the Russian view of things— I shewed Poletica the correspondence between the ex-king of Sweden Gustavus, and the present king Charles John— Forbes was at our house this Evening, and with Mrs Adams and Mary Hellen, I passed part of it at W. S. Smith’s. We had visits from Mr and Mrs S. H. Smith; but Mrs Adams being out they did not stop.

29. V:Mr Joseph Wheaton called upon me this Morning to announce himself as a candidate for the Office of Register of Wills for the County of Washington in this District, in the place of Dr. James H. Blake, who died yesterday. He brought me a large bundle of recommendations, and urged very earnestly his claims, as a revolutionary Officer of great Merit, important services, and now distressed with poverty. After giving a sitting to King, I went to the Office, where Mr Calhoun immediately introduced to me a Mr Van den Bergh a young lawyer who has come from New-York, to solicit the appointment of Consul at Marseilles— Forbes says M. M. Noah has also an inclination for it. Dr Harrison came with recommendations as a revolutionary Officer and a written Application to be appointed Register of Wills— I received despatches from G. W. Campbell, asking permission to return to the United States upon a leave of absence. Mrs Adams rode out this Evening. The day was oppressively warm— I procured an old volume of Newspapers containing A. Hamilton’s Report on the Mint.

30. IV: Read Hamilton’s Report upon the Mint. Found in it information material to my enquiries. Called at King’s; but it was too late to sit. The heat was oppressive. Fahrenheit 88. I called to see R. Forrest who is ill in bed: much alarmed and desponding. Fears it is a paralytic stroke, taken by exposing himself one day last week to the heat of the Sun; great part of the day. Poletica called at my Office to thank me for some St. Petersburg Newspapers, which I sent him yesterday— After dinner I had a visit from W. Lee, with Matthew Carey from Philadelphia, who is going to Philadelphia. We spent the Evening with a party at Mr Middleton’s at Kalorama.

31. V:15. The heat was so extreme—(Fahrenheit at 92) that I rode to and from my Office. Captain M’Kever of the Navy came and made some enquiries, what should be done with certain negroes more than one hundred in number, taken at Pensacola, while it was in our possession, and now removed into the Alabama Territory, or State. They were taken from American vessels; but are claimed as Spanish property. I told him it must be referred to the President on his return— Force was at the Office respecting the contract for printing the Laws of the next Session of Congress— Young Thruston to solicit the appointment of Register of Wills; and Mitchell junr. about the affairs of W. D. Robinson. My only occupation at the Office was examining for the press, the manuscript of the Journals of the old Congress and franking packages for the Post Office.
Day. Differs little from the last Month.
